I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.   Vanuatu is a young and growing country, with most of the population under the age of 30. 
While Vanuatu’s population has increased rapidly over the past decade, average annual growth in 
gross domestic product per capita has been primarily negative, turning positive only in the past few 
years. As a result, Vanuatu is the third poorest country in the Pacific region. With a human poverty 
index of 24.7, Vanuatu is ranked 52nd in the world.1 A looming issue is the large portion of the 
population comprising youth about to enter the workforce—42% of the population is 14 years old or 
younger.2 Jobs are being created far more slowly than the current and future inflow of young 
workers.3 Further, the Government is not meeting the full costs of providing schooling and other 
public services for children. The Institute of Statistics of the United Nations Educational, Scientific 
and Cultural Organization found that only 9.6% of gross domestic product was devoted to public 
education  in  2004.  The  repetition  rate  for  primary  education  is  high  by  regional  standards, 
accounting for 9% of enrollment, and the dropout and attrition rate is also high.4 Consequently, 
poorly  prepared  and  trained  youth  are  entering  a  tight  job  market,  which  offers  them  few 
opportunities to earn a living. Vanuatu does not have much time to address these issues, as some 
estimates indicate that four persons enter the job market for every job created.5 Therefore, rapid 
action is imperative to resolve many of the bottlenecks to job creation and growth. On the positive 
side, Vanuatu has substantial long-term prospects for growth and development. In addition to 
significant agricultural prospects, the country’s natural beauty offers tourism potential.  
 
2.  Many of the building block institutions required for sustained economic development are 
developing, albeit slowly. The Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) strategy for Vanuatu addresses 
fundamental  constraints  to  sustainable,  private  sector-led  economic  growth.  Specifically,  the 
strategy supports the development of an enabling environment for private sector development, 
focusing on strengthening the policy, institutional, and regulatory framework for business; and 
increasing access to finance. Developing and implementing a coherent policy towards the private 
sector is difficult. At a minimum, the Government has a central role in identifying and reducing 
barriers to private sector development. Consistent with the Government’s Priorities and Action 
Agenda (PAA),6 the aim of ADB’s strategy is to (i) encourage economic growth, which has not kept 
pace  with  population  growth;  (ii)  address  low  private  sector  investment;  and  (iii)  reduce 
unemployment.   
 
3.  This technical assistance (TA) will seek to update the laws that are the foundation of 
commercial transactions, while supporting the capacity of Government to implement and monitor 
compliance  with  these  laws.  The  TA7  addresses  the  broad  development  priorities  of  the 
Government, and specifically the Vanuatu Financial Services Commission (VFSC). It is consistent 
with ADB’s Pacific Strategy 2005–2009, and was included in ADB’s country strategy and program 
update (footnote 1). The Government concurs with the TA's objectives, scope, implementation 
arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference. The TA framework is in

II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  Low levels of private investment are indicative of the challenges Vanuatu is facing in trying 
to achieve the economic growth required to provide income-earning opportunities for its population. 
The inherited legal and regulatory framework for business transactions is outdated. As such, it is 
ineffective  in  supporting  the  type  of  modern  business  transactions  that  would  help  establish 
Vanuatu as an internationally reputable and commercially attractive financial center. Following an 
International Monetary Fund assessment,8 a process of reforming the legal, institutional and policy 
framework for the offshore sector is underway. However, much more is needed to establish a 
credible financial and business framework in Vanuatu.  
5.  Some  diagnostic  studies  and  assessments  have  suggested  that  the  legal  business 
framework does not support efficient business activity adequately, and have stressed the need for 
substantial reform.9 Vanuatu’s local laws, which have been carried over from the Republic’s days 
as a condominium,10 contain elements of British Common Law and the French Napoleonic Code. A 
number of impediments have been identified in the Companies Act, which was modeled after the 
1948 and 1967 British Companies Act. The act (i) lacks an express standard of care that forces the 
directors  or officers of  a company  to act in the best interest of the company or its shareholders; 
(ii) inadequately protects minority shareholder rights; (iii) lacks an efficient system for settling 
disputes between the main stakeholders in a company (shareholders, directors, and management); 
and  (iv)  is  superseded  or  conflicts  with  the  many  laws  in  the  financial  sector.  Indeed,  the 
Companies Act, in conjunction with the Vanuatu Banking, Insurance, Stamp Duties, and Trust 
Companies Regulations, form the statutory framework for the operation of the finance sector. 
VFSC administers this framework, which is interpreted by the Supreme Court of Vanuatu. 
6.  The bankruptcy and insolvency framework11 effectively is nonexistent, which increases risks 
for  operating  businesses.  In  the  absence  of  a  specific  Vanuatu  bankruptcy  law,  the  1914 
Bankruptcy Act of United Kingdom is used as a guideline for insolvencies. This results in an 
inefficient system for dealing with corporate liquidations or restructurings. Thus, ways of facilitating 
business rehabilitation urgently need to be found. The new bankruptcy and insolvency law should 
establish an efficient institutional setup for dealing with insolvency proceedings. Further, it should 
assist the Government in promoting investor confidence in the marketplace by providing a fair and 
effective system for restoring assets to productive use, including establishing a framework for 
debtor rehabilitation, a deterrent to fraud, and a public record of estates. 
7.  The companies’ registry costs can be high for small- and medium-scale businesses. The 
law requires a broad range of relatively expensive licenses and registrations, as well as regulatory 
requirements  (e.g.,  preparation  of  a  60–70  page  memorandum  and  articles  of  association  is 
required before company registration). Further, the finance minister and attorney general must 
approve each incorporation. While these layers of bureaucracy have no compensating public policy 
objective, they increase uncertainty and transaction costs for investors. Notarization costs also are 
high, and notaries are granted the power to make rules prescribing their fees.

8.  In December 1993, VFSC was established to regulate and supervise the non-banking 
financial services industry in accordance with Government legislation and international standards. 
As a result, Vanuatu was recognized as having an internationally reputable and commercially 
attractive finance center. Among its duties, VFSC (i) supervises financial business to protect the 
public against financial  losses arising from financial dishonesty, incompetence, and malpractice; 
(ii) generally administers the collection of fees, charges, and other revenues due under the acts; 
(iii)  acts  internationally  as  the  national  authority  on  matters  relating  to  the  supervision  and 
regulation  of  financial business;  and  (iv)  provides  advice  and  assistance  to  the  Government, 
particularly  on  the  preparation  and  submission  of  reports,  and  makes  recommendations  on 
financial business. As a priority of its corporate plan, VFSC has started modernizing its institutional 
and  legal  framework,  making  notable  progress  in  recent  years.  With  the  passage  of  the 
International Banking Act in 2002, VFSC transferred banking supervision responsibilities to the 
Reserve Bank of Vanuatu (RBV).12 In 2005, Parliament passed the new Insurance Act, Protected 
Cell  Companies  Act,  Mutual  Funds  Act,  and  Unit  Trust  Funds  Act.  VFSC  is  revising  the 
International Companies Act, and has initiated the drafting of a new trust law and companies 
services  providers  bill.  With  the  upgrading  of  the  legal framework  underway,  VFSC  must  be 
capable  of  carrying  out  its  responsibilities  for  overseeing  the  new  legislation.  Its  supervision 
capacity needs to be improved to ensure greater compliance with laws and regulations. Further, 
decision making needs to be more open and transparent, and the governance structure of the 
board must be examined to ensure that VFSC performs at a high level and has the ability to act 
efficiently and effectively. Information technology also needs to be updated to ensure that VFSC 
provides accurate and timely services, which will enhance the reputation of Vanuatu as a center of 
financial business. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  This  TA  will  assist  the  Government  in  strengthening  the  framework  for  business 
transactions, thereby improving the reputation and commercial attractiveness of Vanuatu as an 
investment destination that supports international standards and good practice. Specifically, the TA 
will (i) reform the laws and regulations constituting the companies, bankruptcy, and insolvency 
framework; (ii) develop companies’ registry reform road map; and (iii) conduct an assessment of 
VFSC to ensure high corporate governance standards and strong supervisory capabilities. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  Reforming business law will be guided by the following principles:  
(i)  Focus. The legal framework should make setting up, running, and closing a business 
as easy as possible.  
(ii)  Local detail. The legislation should take into account that most Vanuatu businesses 
are small, and that business transactions often involve rural enterprises.  
(iii)  Simplicity. The legislation should be unambiguous in language, cost-effective, and 
easily understood. 
(iv)  Capacity. The legal and supporting institutional design should take into account the 
relatively low level of local capacity. 
                                                 
12 Before 1999, VFSC and RBV divided the supervisory responsibilities for Vanuatu’s financial institutions. However, 
under the Financial Institutions Act of 1999, RBV was granted exclusive supervisory responsibility for domestic banks. 
In addition, under the International Banking Act of 2002, RBV’s responsibility was extended to offshore banks. In 2003, 
Vanuatu National Provident Fund also fell under the supervision of RBV.

4   
(v)  Consultation. In support of the reform process, extensive consultations should be 
undertaken  with  various  stakeholders,  including  the  judiciary,  business  groups, 
accounting and business advisory services, legal practitioners, and the general public. 
The aim is to help improve understanding and build ownership of the reform process, 
and to enhance awareness of the legal reforms and their implications for business. The 
TA  will  ensure  that  critical  links  with  the  ongoing  Secured  Transactions  Reforms13 
process are established.  
11.  The TA will generate the following outputs: (i) draft companies act; (ii) draft bankruptcy and 
insolvency act; (iii) companies’ registry reform road map; and (iv) diagnostic report analyzing the 
policy mandate, as well as the institutional and legal framework, for VFSC and the accompanying 
action plan, including the sequencing and costing of reforms needed for VFSC to fulfill its mandate. 
The TA will have four components. 
 
12.   Part A, support for company act reform, will entail 
 
(i)  a diagnostic study of laws and regulations relating to companies in Vanuatu;  
(ii)  identification through a participatory process of the reforms required in the legal 
framework  for  supervising  companies  and  enhancing  corporate  governance  of 
Vanuatu, taking into account regional and international good practices; 
(iii)  formulation of a white paper on reform of the Companies Act; and 
(iv)  drafting of new act, and recommendations for setting up this act, based on the 
reforms  identified  to  enhance  corporate  governance  and  achieve  consistency 
between the company act and other laws, the proposed bankruptcy and insolvency 
act, and the laws governing different financial organizations. 
 
13.   Part B, support for bankruptcy and insolvency act reform, will entail 
  
(i)  a diagnostic review of laws and regulations relating to bankruptcy and insolvency of 
companies in Vanuatu;  
(ii)  identification through a participatory process of the reforms required in the legal 
framework  for  bankruptcy  and  insolvency,  taking  into  account  regional  and 
international practices; 
(iii)  formulation of a white paper on draft of  the proposed bankruptcy and insolvency 
act; and 
(iv)  drafting of new act to enact the reforms, and recommendations for setting up the 
act. 
 
14.  Part C, companies’ registry reform road map, will entail  
(i)  a  comprehensive  review  of  the  business  processes  of  the  companies’  registry, 
including strategy, organization, structure, segments, and reporting arrangements; 
(ii)  drafting of new companies’ registry road map; and 
(iii)  recommendations and detailed guidelines for implementing reform with respect to 
lodging, processing, and storing business registration information; and making it 
available to relevant users in the private and public sectors based on international 
good practice.  
 
 
                                                 
13 ADB. 2004. Technical Assistance to the Republic of Vanuatu for the Secured Transactions Reforms (Cofinanced by 
the Government of Australia). Manila (TA 4457-VAN, approved on 2 December, for $800,000). No other substantial 
financial sector reforms are ongoing.

5
15.  Part D, capacity building and strengthening of VFSC, will entail 
 
(i)  an analysis of the availability and allocation of VFSC resources and staff capacity to 
implement their regulatory mandate;  
(ii)  a diagnostic study and provision of guidelines for developing VFSC’s (a) systems, 
procedures,  and  capacity  for  market  monitoring  and  surveillance;  (b)  reporting 
requirements and systems to assist in tracking market participants’ compliance with 
VFSC rules and regulations; and (c) enforcement and prosecution mechanisms to 
ensure the effectiveness of the regulations; 
(iii)  preparation of an action plan for sequencing and costing reforms for discussion to 
enable VFSC to fulfill its mandate; and 
(iv)  development of training programs and workshops for VFSC officials to enable VFSC 
to enforce effectively regulations and other prescribed international best practices, 
and surveillance and monitoring systems for all participants. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000 equivalent. The Government has asked ADB to 
finance the equivalent of $800,000. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from ADB's TA 
funding program. The Government will finance the balance of the local currency cost, equivalent to 
$200,000,  through  the  provision  of  counterpart  staff  salaries,  office  accommodation  and 
transportation, support services, and the facilitation of consultations. Detailed cost estimates and 
the financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months, from January 2007 to December 2008. The 
focused reforms to be envisaged in the TA are under VFSC's responsibility. Since VFSC has 
administrative authority within the Government for all TA components, it will be the Executing 
Agency. VFSC will provide office space for consultants and assign a senior counterpart staff 
member to lead the operational aspects of the reform process. The Ministry of Finance and 
Economic Management and the State Law Office (SLO) will contribute to the reform process 
through overall guidance regarding the policies and navigating the legal processes, including 
stakeholder  consultations,  drafting  of  companies  act,  bankruptcy  and  insolvency  act,  and 
companies’ registry road map. The public will participate through extensive consultations with key 
organizations and individuals that make up the stakeholder group. In addition, seminars will be 
organized to discuss the draft acts and the companies’ registry road map. The implementation of 
the TA will require 32 person-months of consulting services (22 person-months international, 10 
person-months  national).  The  international  consultant  team  will  be  recruited  from  a  firm  with 
expertise in (i) business law reforms (including companies and bankruptcy and insolvency laws, 
and companies’ registration); (ii) legal drafting; and (iii) institutional reforms. A national business 
law expert (10 person-months) will complement the international consultants. The outline terms of 
reference  for  the  consultants  are  in  Appendix  3.  The  consultants  will  be  selected  as  an 
international team using the quality- and cost-based selection method, in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2006). 
 
IV.   THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved  the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Vanuatu for Financial Services Commission on Institutional and Legal Reforms, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3    9
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Consultants 
1.  Company Law Expert, Team Leader (international, 5 person-months) 
1.  The  company  law  expert  will  be  a  qualified  lawyer  with  at  least  15  years  professional 
experience.  The  expert  should  have  extensive  experience  in  practicing  law  in  a  common  law 
jurisdiction, in legal and regulatory review, and in preparing draft laws relating to business. The expert 
will have experience in managing legal reform processes in developing countries. The expert will be 
an excellent communicator. Experience with Pacific islands or small states would be an asset. 
2.  The commercial law expert will carry out the following tasks: 
(i)  Review and assess the Companies Act, all related legislation and regulations, and 
implementing and supporting institutions; and determine whether new act is needed.  
(ii)  Assess issues pertinent to corporate governance, and the extent to which these should 
be incorporated into the new act. Review international best practice in companies act 
reform. Summarize findings and recommendations in a comprehensive, concise report, 
and present it to stakeholders.  
(iii)  Consider the needs of small businesses, especially those in rural areas. Identify and 
assess corporate structures that take into account the traditional and rural business 
environment. Develop reform performance indicators and collect baseline data. 
(iv)  Consider relevant legal enforcement issues, and discuss options for reform. Take into 
account existing weak enforcement mechanisms for the Companies Act reform. 
(v)  Coordinate with the ongoing Secured Transactions Reforms activities, and ensure full 
compatibility between the two reforms. 
(vi)  Coordinate  closely  with  company  registration  and  bankruptcy  and  insolvency  law 
experts to assess related areas and ensure harmonization between them. 
(vii)  Initiate stakeholder discussions, and raise public awareness of the underlying problems 
and  the  need  for  business  law  reform  in  general  and  companies  act  reform  in 
particular.  
(viii)  Formulate a white paper on reform of the Companies Act. Lead related consultations. 
(ix)  Oversee the legal drafting process on the Companies Act in close cooperation with 
legal drafting expert and State Law Office (SLO); present the draft(s) to stakeholders. 
Initiate wider public consultations.  
(x)  Identify and assess related legal and regulatory reform areas that should be candidates 
for the Government’s business law reform agenda forwarding the future. Present the 
findings to Government and other stakeholders, and include them in the final technical 
assistance report (TA). 
(xi)  Prepare  and  submit  inception,  progress,  and  final  reports;  effectively  lead  the 
consultant team; and take overall responsibility for and ownership of the delivery of 
expected TA outputs and outcomes. 
2.  Bankruptcy and Insolvency Law Expert (international, 5 person-months) 
3.  The consultant will be a qualified lawyer with at least 15 years of professional experience. He 
will have an expertise in insolvency law, banking, and corporate debt restructuring, and related 
insolvency practices in a common law jurisdiction. The expert will be an excellent communicator and 
have experience in managing legal reform processes in developing countries. Experience with Pacific 
islands or small states would be an asset. 
4.  The consultant will carry out the following duties: 
(i)  Review  the  bankruptcy  regime  currently  in  effect,  including  a  quantitative  and 
qualitative analysis of the practice of lenders and borrowers of bankruptcy proceedings, 
and of institutional capabilities for compliance with and enforcement of bankruptcy 
laws. Summarize findings and recommendations in a comprehensive, concise report.

10  Appendix 3 
(ii)  Prepare the initial studies, which will include a brief summary of the features of various 
insolvency  regimes  and  their  deficiencies,  and  identify  options  for  revising  current 
bankruptcy law and related procedures and improving institutional capabilities. 
(iii)  Coordinate  closely  with  the  company  law  expert.  Assess  issues  related  to  the 
Companies Act, and ensure their smooth integration into the legislation governing the 
proposed draft of the bankruptcy and insolvency act. 
(iv)  Organize a workshop on insolvency with stakeholders to present a comprehensive 
report and discuss the initial studies, a broad strategy for bankruptcy law reform, and 
recommendations on actions to implement such reform. Prepare summaries of the 
workshop discussions, and produce the final report. 
(v)  In close consultation with the international commercial law consultant and national law 
consultant define  the principles  that  should underpin  the  new  insolvency  act,  and 
recommend the most appropriate institutional framework for corporate insolvency. 
(vi)  Formulate a white paper on draft of the proposed bankruptcy and insolvency act. Lead 
related consultations. 
(vii)  Oversee  the  legal  drafting  process  on  bankruptcy  and  insolvency  act  in  close 
cooperation with the legal drafting expert and SLO. Ensure that the act contains, inter 
alia, provisions relating to the institutional framework for dispute resolution and the 
rules and procedures for liquidation and restructuring of companies, as well as the 
liquidation and restructuring of companies. 
(viii)  Present the draft(s) to stakeholders and Asian Development Bank (ADB). Initiate wider 
public consultations.  
(ix)  Submit the draft acts and reports to the team leader, so that the team leader can 
ensure consistency in the draft company act and the draft bankruptcy and insolvency 
act. 
(x)  Make public presentations on the economic consequences of the reform. 
(xi)  Coordinate  responses  to  inquiries  and  questions  by  stakeholders  and  the  public. 
Confirm  that  answers  to  questions  explain,  as  appropriate,  how  the  economic 
objectives of the law affect drafting choices. 
(xii)  Identify and assess related legal and regulatory reform areas that should be candidates 
for the Government’s law reform agenda forwarding the future. Present the findings to 
Government and other stakeholders, and include them in the final TA report. 
3.  Company Registration Expert (international, 3 person-months) 
5.  The  company  registration  expert  will  have  a  master’s  degree  in  economics,  business 
administration, law, information technology, or a similar field. The expert will have at least 15 years 
relevant professional experience, including in developing countries, in analyzing company registration 
processes, reviewing underlying legislation, and implementing related reform processes. Relevant 
experience in the Pacific islands would be an asset. 
6.   The expert will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  Review good international practice with respect to lodging, processing, and storing 
business registration information and making it available to relevant users in the private 
and  public  sectors.  This  should  address  upfront  registration  as  well  as  ongoing 
registration requirements. Special consideration should be given to good practice in 
similar operating environments. 
(ii)  Review existing company legislation and regulations, in close cooperation with the 
company law expert, to identify areas and requirements that are inconsistent with best 
international practice. Provide relevant recommendations to feed into the drafting of the 
companies act. 
(iii)  Review  the  business  processes  of  the  companies’  registry,  including  (a)  strategy; 
organization, structure, and reporting arrangements; (b) availability and allocation of

Appendix 3    11
resources, including staff capacity to implement the proposed new system; (c) nature 
and quality of stakeholder relationships; and (d) delivery of products and services. 
(iv)  Consult  with  the  users  of  business  name  and  companies’  registry  information  to 
determine information needs, and consider accessibility and cost-effectiveness. Take 
into account the requirements of users in relatively remote areas, and the potential for 
electronic access. 
(v)  Review  the  institutional  arrangements  for  the  companies’  registry,  as  housed  in 
Vanuatu Financial Services Commission (VFSC). 
(vi)  Assess the needs of the companies’ registry regarding the development of appropriate 
software  and  hardware  for  a  new  registry  system,  taking  into  consideration  local 
information technology development and local capacities. 
(vii)  Assess the costs associated with maintaining the current system, and the revenues 
generated by the current fee structure. 
(viii)  Coordinate closely with and support the commercial law expert with the diagnostic 
work, and make specific recommendations on harmonizing the proposed companies’ 
registry reform and the larger Companies Act reform. 
(ix)  Help the commercial law expert in developing reform performance indicators, and 
collect baseline data on the business registry. 
(x)  Take into account the ongoing Secured Transactions Reforms Process, particularly 
with respect to the proposed secured transactions notice filing archive. 
(xi)  Make final recommendations, closely harmonized with the reform of the Companies 
Act. The final report for the diagnostic phase will include an assessment of feasible 
reform  options  and  final  recommendations,  including  all  details  required  for 
implementation (technical, costs, and consultant terms of reference). 
4.  Institutional Reform Expert (international, 3 person-months) 
7.   The  institutional  reform  expert  will  have  a  master’s  degree  in  economics,  business 
administration, law, information technology, or a similar field. The expert will have at least 15 years 
professional experience in institutional reforms. The expert will have experience in managing legal 
reform processes in developing countries. The expert will be an excellent communicator. Relevant 
experience in the Pacific islands would be an asset. 
8.  The expert will focus on the following tasks: 
(i)  Examine the legal and institutional framework of VFSC and regulations governing 
business activity and associated institutions. 
(ii)  Review and evaluate which areas of the VFSC institutional framework and policies are 
acceptable  and  follow  best  practices,  and  provide  initial  recommendations  on 
reorienting the relevant areas in the framework to ensure best practices are in place. 
(iii)  Analyze  the  availability  and  allocation  of  VFSC  resources  and  staff  capacity  to 
implement their regulatory mandate. 
(iv)  Examine the organizational structure, particularly the extent of separation of roles and 
responsibilities between departments and risk management groups. Assess whether 
the safeguards are sufficient to ensure adequate internal control and oversight. 
(v)  Formulate and redraft VFSC’s policies and procedures for corporate governance.  
(vi)  Prepare a reform diagnostic, including an action plan that identifies reform issues, as 
well  as  prioritization,  sequencing,  and  costing  of  reform  agenda  implementation. 
Ensure  that  the  new  action  plan  achieves  the  following:  (a)  the  new  legislation 
governing bankruptcy, companies, and trusts is up to date, reflects international best 
practice, and encourages development of innovative products; (b) improved corporate 
management processes of VFSC are implemented by reviewing and updating the 
corporate,  human  resource  development,  information  technology,  and  other 
management  improvement  plans; and  (c)  reporting  requirements  and  systems are

12  Appendix 3 
developed to ensure a high level of compliance by local and exempt companies with 
statutory reporting and other requirements. 
(vii)  Present recommendations and details for implementing reforms based on international 
best  practices,  including  implementation  components,  financial  feasibility  of  the 
preferred reform option, performance indicators and targets, and implementation risks. 
(viii)  Organize  extensive  consultations  with  VFSC  officials  and  other  stakeholders,  and 
develop the training programs and workshops to help improve understanding and build 
ownership of the reform process. 
5.  Legal Drafting Expert (international, 4 person-months) 
9.  The  legal  drafting  expert  will  be  a  qualified  lawyer  with  at  least  15  years  professional 
experience.  The  expert  should  have  extensive  experience  in  practicing  law  in  a  common  law 
jurisdiction, in legal and regulatory review, and in preparing drafts on companies and bankruptcy and 
insolvency acts. The candidate will have experience in managing legal reform processes in developing 
countries. Experience with Pacific islands or small states would be an asset. 
10.  The legal drafting expert, in close coordination with SLO, will: 
(i)  Review and provide recommendations on (a) drafting instructions on the companies act 
prepared by the international company law consultant, (b) drafting instructions on the 
bankruptcy and insolvency act prepared by the international bankruptcy and insolvency 
law consultant, and (c) drafting inception reports relating to the legal aspects prepared 
by the international consultants. 
(ii)  Undertake the drafting of the companies act and bankruptcy and insolvency act, and 
present them to the company and bankruptcy and insolvency law experts. 
(iii)  Conduct workshops to discuss the final drafts with the international consultants, ADB’s 
task manager, and country stakeholders. 
6.  Legal Peer Reviewers (international, 2 person-months total) 
11.  The consulting firm will retain two legal peer reviewers to provide strategic advice on the 
reform process, and to comment on (i) the Companies Act review reports, Bankruptcy Act review 
reports,  and  companies’  registry  review  reports;  (ii)  draft  companies  act,  draft  bankruptcy  and 
insolvency act, and companies’ registry road map; and (iii) the larger commercial law reform agenda. 
The experts will have law degree (preferably master of law or Juris Doctor) and at least 20 years of 
relevant professional experience in practicing or teaching law in a common law jurisdiction, and in 
legal and regulatory review. The legal peer reviewers will have strong academic backgrounds, work 
experience in the Pacific islands, and knowledge of legal reform processes in developing countries. 
12.  Specifically, based on relevant economic and legal analysis, and the diagnostic report on the 
legal business environment, the international legal reviewers will undertake the following: 
(i)  Provide guidance on the law reform strategy established by the company law and 
bankruptcy and insolvency law experts, 
(ii)  Review  and  comment  on  the  companies  act  review  reports  and  bankruptcy  and 
insolvency  act  review  reports;  the  companies  and  bankruptcy  and  insolvency  act 
reform white paper; and the companies and bankruptcy and insolvency acts to ensure 
that  they  are  in  accordance  with  international  best  practice  and  reflect  the  latest 
practical examples of well-functioning company and bankruptcy and insolvency acts, 
especially in the small island context. 
(iii)  Provide advice and feedback to help resolve drafting problems. 
13.  Substantial comments and suggestions by the legal reviewers will be copied to the ADB task 
manager and the steering committee secretariat, and will be incorporated in the final consultant 
report.

Appendix 3    13
7.  Business Law Expert (national, 10 person-months) 
14.  The  business  law  consultant  will  have  a  law  degree  and  be  licensed  to  practice  law  in 
Vanuatu. The expert will be a locally recognized expert in business law, particularly company law. 
This is a senior position requiring at least 10 years’ experience. 
15.  The expert will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  Work  with  the  international  experts,  government  stakeholders,  local  business 
community  and  legal  practitioners,  and  general  public.  Provide  the  international 
consultants with local perspectives on problems and options for solutions regarding the 
company and bankruptcy legislations. Provide guidance to the international consultants 
on local culture and perspectives, as required. 
(ii)  Work with the commercial law and bankruptcy and insolvency law experts in identifying 
elements in Vanuatu laws and regulations relevant to the company and bankruptcy and 
insolvency legislation. 
(iii)  Review reports and legal drafts submitted by the commercial law expert, comment on 
these drafts, and advise the international consultants and ADB on Vanuatu’s law. 
(iv)  Under the guidance of the steering committee and the team leader, and in close 
cooperation with VFSC, take a leading role in the consultation process. 
(v)  Help train local government officials, legal practitioners, business community members, 
and business development service providers in comprehending the new company and 
bankruptcy acts. 
B.  Reporting 
16.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months, from January 2007 to December 2008, with 
intermittent inputs from the international and national consultants. The companies and bankruptcy and 
insolvency acts are expected to be drafted within 12 months of commencement of the TA. Hence, 
consultant inputs will focus on delivery within the first 12 months of TA implementation. An additional 
12  months  are  allocated  for  the  revision  and  advocacy  of  the  companies  and  bankruptcy  and 
insolvency acts, capacity building in the application of the new companies’ registry, and relevant 
follow-up legal work, as required. 
17.  Within 6 weeks of the commencement of the TA, the team leader will submit an inception 
report, including a detailed work plan and conceptual issues relevant to project delivery. Within 6 
months of commencement of the TA, an interim report will be submitted containing (i) the first drafts of 
the companies act and bankruptcy and insolvency act and respective white papers; (ii) the draft 
reform road map for the company registration system; and (iii) the companies act and bankruptcy and 
insolvency act reforms performance indicators, including baseline data. A midterm report containing 
the final draft of the companies act and bankruptcy and insolvency act, the final reform road map for 
the company registration system, and the work program for continued training and additional legal 
follow-up work will be submitted within 12 months of TA commencement. The team leader will submit 
progress reports after each field visit. A comprehensive draft final report will be submitted at least 6 
weeks before the final tripartite meeting. A final report will be submitted 4 weeks after receipt of the 
comments by ADB and Government counterparts.
